normalised: Load shedding, or as some sarcastically call it, "planned inconvenience," is basically when the power company deliberately cuts off electricity supply to certain areas. Think of it like this: imagine your building only has enough biryani to feed half the residents. Rationing it out is kinda like load shedding. They do it to prevent the whole system from collapsing when demand is much higher than supply.

normalised: Now, why does this happen so often in India, especially during scorching months? Well, blame it on a combination of factors. Firstly, the infrastructure, especially in older cities, isn’t always up to the mark. Some lines are still carrying more load than they were designed for, leading to frequent breakdowns. Secondly, demand skyrockets in the summer – everyone cranking up their A C s, coolers, and refrigerators, all at once. It's like a constant power struggle for energy.

normalised: The thing is, load shedding doesn't just mean a sweaty night. It affects businesses, small and big. Imagine running a small Kirana store in a village and not being able to keep your fridge running – huge losses, right? It even affects studies. Try memorizing those history dates for your Class ten exams by the flickering light of a candle!
